div.p:
IF thou ha≈øt peru≈øed that ungodly Pamphlet of Mr Humfreys for Free Admi≈ø≈øion, and taken notice in it of that ma≈ø≈øe of perverting the Scripture by malice or ignorance, or both; of his ≈øtriking hands with all the ignorant and prophane enemies of Reformation in the Land; Of his much ≈øelf-condemning Sophi≈øtry, tending to de≈øtroy all Church-Reformation; Of his carnall and little better then prophane rea≈øoning; Of his pretendod love to the in bewitching thy con≈øcience into

as now the ignorant, prophane, formall; and ≈øuper≈øtitious do, have re≈øolved to deal with him in a brotherly way.

Ble≈ø≈øed be God we can wa≈øh our hands from the guilt of any prejudice again≈øt Mr H. per≈øon, for we know him not, neither have heard of any that did; and we can with chearfulne≈øs ≈øay, Had not the glory of God, the danger of infection by the ≈øpreading this erroneous Pamphlet, the experience of the hurt it hath already done, the clearing of the Mini≈øters of England from being all ≈øuch ≈øoul-murderers and pleaders for Baal, and la≈øtly, had we not thought it our duty to bear witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt this abomination, verily we had ≈øaid nothing, but in ≈øilence bewailed M.H. and the ≈øad fruit of his labour again≈øt the purity of Chri≈øts wor≈øhip; What we have done we commit to the hands of the Lord, that he may glorifie him≈øelf by it. And we did the rather in the ≈øtrength of God adventure to oppo≈øe the cheering up the enemies of Reformation in this deplorable Apo≈øtacy, becau≈øe the Lord laid it upon our hearts to tremble at that word of his Eze. 13.22. Becau≈øe with lies you have made the hearts of the righteous ≈øad, whom I have not made ≈øad, and
≈øtrengthned the hands of the wicked, that he ≈øhould not return from his wicked way, by promi≈øing him life, therefore ye ≈øhall ≈øee no more vanity, nor divine divinations, for I will deliver my people out of your hand, and ye ≈øhall know that I am the Lord; we fear the ≈øad Judgements of God upon the ≈øpreaders of this Pamphlet, when Chri≈øt ≈øhall come to be revenged on the oppo≈øers of his Kingdom.

We have but few daies before this our An≈øwer want to the Pre≈ø≈øe, ≈øeen an An≈øwer to this Pamphlet by Dr Drake (for which we ble≈ø≈øe God) more ≈øtrict and acute then ours (intended for our people) which may haply be more ≈øatisfactory to ≈øome then ours may ≈øeem to be; le≈øt any ≈øhould ≈øay We have built upon him or borrowed from him, we can profe≈ø≈øe we have not borrowed ≈øo much as a line from him: And truly we can ≈øay with an hone≈øt heart unfeignedly, that we long to ≈øee all the Godly Mini≈øters declare again≈øt this piece, for we finde, if men of greater parts and much per≈øpicuity labour not ≈øuddenly to da≈øh this idol out of countenance; the≈øe convictions in ≈øuch a ca≈øe (where ≈øo many cry Great is Diana) will work in the prophane wits
of this Nation all manner of concupi≈øcen≈øe, Rom. 7.8.

Do not then Chri≈øtian Reader, (out of a vain fear that by this An≈øwer thou ≈øhalt be drawn into ≈øeparation from the godly) be ≈øo prejudiced as to forbear to pouder; neither think thou that we intend to be Sci≈ømaticall in not complying with Godly Mini≈øters in a work of reall Reformation, according to the Word of God. The thing herd pleaded for in the Preamble, is the nece≈ø≈øity of Reformation, as the ca≈øe ≈øtands, to begin with the minor part, voluntarily uniting together with their own Mini≈øter to ≈øubmit to Di≈øcipline (the major part being de≈øperately overwhelmed with ignorance, prophanene≈ø≈øe, and ≈øuper≈øtition, ≈øtrangers to and for≈øakers of their Covenant with God in Bapti≈øm) by conforming with their own mouths their part of the Covenant of God, a thing as our fir≈øt Reformers in the Rubrick before confirmation, as al≈øo Calvin, Bucer, Dr Fulk, and others affirm to be the practi≈øe of the Primitive Church, and may be now much more needfull. This is, ble≈ø≈øed be God, in ≈øome of our Pari≈øhes fruitfully embraced.

Reader, We wi≈øh thee in the Lord to take heed of ≈øtriking hands with the Abettors of Free Admi≈ø≈øion, le≈øt thy end be wor≈øe then thy beginning, and we commit thee to him who is able to keep his from partaking with other mens ≈øinnes and plagues.

div.p: BEfore we yet enter upon the ≈øubject it ≈øelf, give us leave, Reader, further to import unto thee, what hath given us this encouragement, and indeed laid an invincible engagement upon our ≈øpirits, as to the bearing witne≈øs again≈øt this vile piece.

We the unworthie≈øt of the ≈øervants of Chri≈øt, having with many others, long waited for the practice of Reformation in the Parochial Congregations of this
Nation (as the fruit of the prayers, tears and bloud of the Lords people.) And though there have been expedients held forth, yet finding they lay dead upon the ≈øpirits of too many, it plea≈øed the Lord to ≈øtirre us up, though the la≈øt and lea≈øt of our Brethren, to enquire after him in this matter, labouring (as far as we were able) to lay a≈øide all prejudices and prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, as to the different wayes were held forth by holy men in the Nation, and ≈øo to pur≈øue in the Lords ≈øtrength what he ≈øhould plea≈øe to clear unto us to be his will, and to impre≈øs upon our hearts, and accordingly to practi≈øe it: Upon this we betook our ≈øelves to publick Humiliation in Fa≈øting and Prayer in our re≈øpective places, as al≈øo to private weekly ≈øeeking the Lord together, and conference, in which duties we found the Lord greatly aba≈øing our ≈øpirits before him, for the great neglects which had been upon u as to this duty, and we were even afraid to plead with our God, con≈øidering how greatly we had failed, and put off the work of Reformation from our ≈øpirits, and the many ≈øore and great evils the Lord was pleas'd to di≈øcover
upon our hearts, ≈øpecially that great ≈ønare (which we de≈øire with all humility to declare to the prai≈øe of God, and the admonition of our Brethren) in which we had been long held, viz.

That reforming our Congregations could not be attain'd, but by a Law from the Supream Magi≈øtrate, thereby exonerating our ≈øelves of the duties the Lord required from us, and the laying the guilt at their door, which the Lord hath now ≈øhew'd us to be a very ≈øhift; and we con≈øider 'tis a great mercy that we have protection from the Magi≈øtrate in the peaceable practice of our con≈øciences.

2. We are convine'd and finde that 'tis the power of the Go≈øpel, the Spirit working by it, that is the only expedient to bring a people to a more clo≈øe and holy fellow≈øhip together, by their willing and mutual ≈øubjection to the rule of the Lord Je≈øus over them; We take it to be derogatory from him, for a people to be forc'd by humane power into the full fellow≈øhip of the Church; ≈øutable to the≈øe convincements, we endeavour'd to clear unto our people, the nature of Church-fellow≈øhip, and the way of it,
and the nece≈ø≈øity of Di≈øcipline, and ≈øo to call upon them to joyn with us in the Lords work, that we might give up our ≈øelves unto him, in a profe≈ø≈øed ≈øubjection to the Go≈øpel, and to grow to a more clo≈øe fellow≈øhip together, that all Ordinances might be duly admini≈øtred, to the honour of Chri≈øt, and that formality and lukewarmne≈øs might be in ≈øome mea≈øure broken. Accordingly an Expedient or Profe≈ø≈øion was drawn up, wherein we acknowledging our former abominations in Wor≈øhip, and profe≈ø≈øing our Repentance before the Lord for them, do ≈øolemnly enter into, and renew our Covenant with God, that he may be our God, and we his people, to own the Lord Je≈øus in his Offices, to ≈øubmit to godly Order and Di≈øcipline, to watch over one another, to walk in mutual edification, knit together in love, and ≈øo receiving others as the Lord ≈øhall over-power their hearts, ≈øome account of them≈øelves being given, and no ju≈øt exception (in a charitable judgement) to be made again≈øt them; This being the known duty of every compleat member in a particular Church, as in effect granted by both the godly parties, we conceived
few or none who were for purity would ≈øtick at it, the want of which practice we take to be the main rea≈øon of ≈øuch great corruptions in the mixt Congregations, which corruptions, we humbly conceive, do put us inevitably upon this practice, if Reformation be really effected; That the ≈øub≈øtance of this is practi≈øed by the Presbyterian Brethren, though differing in the expedient, is ≈øufficiently clear by the practice of the London Presbytery, who call upon all, and receive ≈øuch as freely tender them≈øelves, and require an account of them, waiting for the coming in of the re≈øt, which are much the greater party in mo≈øt Pari≈øhes, without Excommunicating ≈øuch as refu≈øe upon what account ≈øoever, to our be≈øt information, and ≈øo the minor party do withdraw from the greater, which the corruption of the greater part (in their enmity to Reformation) doth put them and us upon, unle≈øs we will content our ≈øelves with the ≈øetting up a meer form of Di≈øcipline, but indeed ≈øit down again on the fame lees of formality, which the Lord hath in ≈øore judgements ≈øo much witne≈ø≈øed again≈øt, and his ≈øoul abhorreth. To take the
boldne≈øs of a word more, as to our godly Brethren: We humbly conceive, that if that our Principle agreed upon by the mo≈øt of the different wayes (viz. That every particular Congregation hath power to reform it ≈øelf, and ≈øo Mini≈øters to be helpfull to each other in it) were really practis'd; the controver≈øie of Appeals would quickly cea≈øe. And further (which is al≈øo on both hands granted) that an A≈ø≈øembly of the Officers of ≈øeveral Churches in the Name of Chri≈øt, is an Ordinance of Chri≈øt for the healing of differences, the conte≈øt, Whether this power ≈øhall be ≈øtiled Juridical or Declarative, and whether this A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhould actually excommunicate or declare the fact to be excommunicable, would ≈øurely cea≈øe: It is very ≈øad that a controver≈øie about Appeals, which happily in well-order'd Churches, may rarely be needfull, ≈øhould hinder us in the practice of the fir≈øt Principles which all agree in for the ≈øub≈øtance of them, and ≈øhould make us draw har≈øh con≈øequences from one anothers premi≈ø≈øes, which both di≈øavow, and ≈øo lay ≈øtumbling blocks in the wayes of the weak, and hinder the hoped ≈øucce≈øs of
the Go≈øpel and Reformation in the Nation: Let us fir≈øt have our Churches form'd up and order'd according to Go≈øpel-rules, the ignorant and profane withdrawn from (≈øince 'tis clear they cannot be regularly ca≈øt out by Di≈øcipline) and then the way of tho≈øe Churches holding Communion together, would naturally fall in: To this practice (by the good hand of the Lord) we have mutually given up our ≈øelves, and engaged in the Lord to be helpfull to each other, and to hold Communion together, and a day of ≈ømall things is wit us, yea we have had very precious te≈øtimonies of the Lords pre≈øence with it, with ≈øome of us, for which we ble≈øs him, and our eyes are upon him to bring his own work to pa≈øs, who is able to work and none ≈øhall let it, I≈øa. 43.13.
The good Lord pardon us, if we are not clean≈øed according to the purifying of the Sanctuary.
We ≈øhall yet for further ≈øatisfaction, briefly give an an≈øwer to the mo≈øt common objections to, and mi≈øunder≈øtandings of our practice.

It is enquired in what relation do we conceive our ≈øelves to ≈øtand unto the
re≈øt, and how doe we e≈øteem of them?

1. As to the weak (but not ob≈øtinate) that have not ≈øtrength enough to come up to this practice, we conceive it the Mini≈øters duty to labour their convincement in publick and private, and the united Brethren to do their duty, by praying for them, and to labour to draw them on to them, by all good wayes and means, and not to neglect them.

2. To ≈øuch as peremptorily deny to ≈øubject to Chri≈øts Di≈øcipline, upon indeed a profane account, they doe virtually excommunicate them≈øelves (at lea≈øt from that particular Church) for being called upon to walk with them in the ≈øubjection and fellow≈øhip of the Go≈øpel, they utterly refu≈øe ≈øo to do, but will continue in that loo≈øe e≈øtate, and though they were baptized, yet by their refu≈øing to ≈øubject to Chri≈øt, they are as ∆≤r≈øin ≈øpeaks Deficientes √† ≈øuo Bapti≈ømo, Cap. de di≈øcip & excom. ≈øuch as for the pre≈øent make void the fruit of their Bapti≈øm (though if they are after called we do not a≈ø≈øert a nece≈ø≈øity of renewing it) and to admit ≈øuch to the Lords Supper, were, as that acute Author ju≈øtly
≈øaith, and is evident from the Word, to confound and make one the Church of Chri≈øt and the Kingdom of the devil, as we ≈øhall (God willing) demon≈øtrate in this Di≈øcour≈øe; and though they pretend to profe≈ø≈øe and know God, yet factis negant foedus Dei, they deny him and his Covenant in their works and lives,Tit. 1.16. and ≈øo ought not to be admitted to the Seals of it.
